channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Why let Silicon Valley have all the Fun? Perl Developer job in Cyberjaya / Kuala Lumpur
item.description: Our client is a financial company whose growth over the last twenty years has been nothing short of impressive. They started with the idea that online trading should be available to all, and from there, they’ve built a company with multiple locations worldwide. If you want to be part of a business that is thriving, this may be the perfect opportunity for you.

item.title: How do you look in a fig leaf? Perl role in Cambridge, UK
item.description: This organization is one of the world’s leading developers of medical diagnostic technologies and clinical software. Isn’t it about time you felt positive about what you do? Your work will be used by the NHS, research labs, and worldwide healthcare providers to save lives.

item.title: Business Casual has a Whole New Meaning. Perl role in South Germany
item.description: Online shopping, socializing, working—it’s a digital world now, which is perfect for our client. As an international IT company managing millions of domains for retail and corporate customers in nearly every country in the world, they’re busier than ever—and they need a few senior Perl developers to help them continue to thrive.

item.title: If it was Good Enough for Mozart - Perl role in Vienna
item.description: As one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries, they know all about finding the best products at the best price. They want to find a Perl programmer who thrives on delivering quality content, well-executed user information that’s easy to understand, and is as committed to transparency and excellence as they are.

item.title: Better than Chocolate Chip Cookies! Europe Based Remote Perl role
item.description: While the client operates out of a London office, you also have the option to work remotely. As an online tech publication with over 40 million readers around the world, they know a thing or two about keeping it fresh. Working as a Perl developer, you’ll be responsible for consultation, design, development, testing, and deployment.

item.title: Starship Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, December 9, 2020; 5:30 PM EST

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Quantum::Superpositions, 2021 election
item.description: Thursday, December 3, 2020, 6:30 PM PST

item.description: Wednesday, November 25, 2020; 7:00 PM GMT+1

item.title: What adding CI to 30 projects revealed
item.description: Primarily, that I need to find a way to show how a CI system can benefit CPAN authors to find issues with their code before it reaches CPAN and before they are alerted by the CPAN Testers.

item.title: Tests are awesome!
item.description: Just being all cheery about writing tests. I really like doing so, as I think they really help.

item.title: I need to create a simple and stupid game for myself
item.description: Gabor: I am wasting too much time on a simple and stupid game. I should find or create some other game that is rather simple, but that if I am playing it, it might be actually useful to some.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great modules released last week.

item.title: Github Actions for Perl running on Windows, Mac OSX, and Ubuntu Linux
item.description: One example of how Dave Cross is using GitHub Actions as a CI system.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 086
item.description: Simon's short and simple blog post is still very intriguing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 86: Sudoku Difference
item.description: Big fan of Roger - yet another cool blog post showing the magic of the puzzles.

item.title: Weekly Challenge #086 Task #2 :: (Raku)
item.description: Reading Myoungjin's blog is like reading a Raku text book. Everything is so nicely explained.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 086
item.description: Lubos blogs again after a long gap. It is worth the wait. Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 86: Pair Differences and Sudoku Puzzles
item.description: Laurent's explanation of the Sudoku puzzle is the best introduction to the problem.

item.title: PWC086 - Sudoku Puzzle
item.description: Flavio made a difficult task look simple. Amazing blog post.

item.title: PWC086 - Pair Difference
item.description: Flavio shared his solution to Pair Difference with a cool discussion.

item.title: CY's Take on PWC#086
item.description: Cheok-Yin impressed me with his blog post. It looks like a chapter from a text book. Great Job.

item.title: A Different Puzzle with Raku and Perl
item.description: It gives me immense pleasure every time Arne attempts a Perl solution. Amazing blogging skill as well.

item.title: Challenge 086
item.description: Andinus shared a blog post about his solution to Pair Difference.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 86, Part 2
item.description: You don't want to miss Abigail's blog post as he has done a great job.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 86, Part 1
item.description: Abigail is at his best when he is showing the power of Perl, C, SQL and Node.js.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 86, Part 1
item.description: Abigail never fails to impress me with his solutions. Reading his blog is even more fun.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 084
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 086
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Pair Difference" and "Sudoku Puzzle" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 087
item.description: Welcome to a new week with couple of fun tasks "Longest Consecutive Sequence" and "Largest Rectangle". If you are new to the Weekly Challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Is it possible to return to development with traditional P5P mailing lists?
item.description: Yuki started a very interesting discussion. What do you think?

item.title: Hanging Persistent Volumes in Kubernetes
item.description: Flavio continued playing with Kubernetes with regard to Persistent Volumes.

item.title: Pointer to element
item.description: Flavio shared a gem of code to traverse a hash of hashes to get to a specific item.

item.title: Find fishy Pods in Kubernetes
item.description: Flavio was playing with Kubernetes in his blog post to figure out pods.

item.title: Perl Podcasts
item.description: Samir has compiled a really cool podcast collection. Please do check it out.

item.title: Blogs
item.description: Number of posts last week: BPO: 3; DevTo: 6; Perl.com: 1; PerlAcademy: 1; PerlHacks: 0; PerlMaven: 1; Reddit: 15; TPF: 1;

item.title: CPAN uploads
item.description: Last week there were a total of 205 uploads to CPAN of 138 distinct distributions by 84 different authors. Number of distributions with link to VCS: 121. Number of distros with CI: 59.

item.title: How to build Perl without a compiler?
item.description: When it comes to cloud-based Perl build systems, ActiveState was one of the first to provide a non-local build experience (PPM). Today, the ActiveState Platform features a catalog of dependencies imported from CPAN that you can use to automatically build far more dependencies than PPM ever could.

item.title: #486 - Why do we use Perl?
item.description:
Hi there

I have been asked this question many times. And I always find it hard to answer. Recently I came across a post on Facebook which started the discussion once again. I am pleasantly surprised by some of the response to this question.

I am sure you must have come across, CPAN Dashboard, by Dave Cross. I loved the idea. I have yet to try it myself, but I am certainly going to get my hands dirty soon. If you are a CPAN module author then please give it a go and share your experience with us. Let's make this as popular as CPAN itself.

On a similar note, Gabor Szabo, started the CPAN Digger project. I remember many years ago, Gabor shared the idea with me and wanted me to work on this. Unfortunately I never got around to it. I am so happy that it is finally arrived. It would be great if we all come along and help with the project.

A recent post by Samir Parikh, brought up the topic of "Perl Podcasts" once again. I still remember Lance Wicks and I discussed the subject during the Perl Conference in Glasgow in 2018. We even recorded our first interview together with a very popular face in the Perl commnunity. What a shame I couldn't give the attention it needed. I am still hopeful one day we will get it back in action.

Last but not least, how are the various forms of lockdown treating you in your own country? Please do look after yourself and your family. Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
